Award.AwardTitle: Seismic Site Response Analysis Considering Partially Saturated Soil Conditions

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The seismic response of partially saturated soils differs from that of dry or water saturated soil deposits. Yet, the available site response analysis methods ignore the influence of partial saturation in the soil. This research will study the effects of partial saturation on the seismic site response analysis and how different suction (degree of saturation) profiles affect the seismic response of a soil layer. Suction due to partial saturation increases the effective stresses acting on the soil, altering the shear modulus, shear wave velocity, nonlinear deformation response, and damping. As a result, the distribution of suction with depth is expected to affect the propagation of seismic waves and the resulting ground accelerations. This, in turn, influences the seismic demand imposed on the soil and surface structures. Although the shear wave velocity employed in current site response analysis methods accounts for partial saturation of the soil, it only reflects the degree of saturation at the time of shear wave velocity measurement. Hence, the seasonal fluctuation of the water table and its impact on degree of saturation may alter the site response. The current state of practice commonly relies on procedures that include dynamic material properties of either water saturated or dry soils as the most conservative scenarios. This might be an appropriate assumption for problems dealing with soils' strength and deformation. However, stiffer partially saturated soils due to inter-particle suction forces result in a higher site natural frequency and lower damping, which may adversely affect the site response. In this study, the steady state-infiltration through an unsaturated soil layer inside a geotechnical centrifuge will be implemented to control the soil layer?s degree of saturation. Cyclic loads with different amplitudes and frequencies, and earthquake motions with different intensities will be applied to the soil layers with various suction profiles. These profiles are controlled by the infiltration rate and the centrifugal acceleration. The experimental data will be compared with the numerically estimated site responses incorporating effective stress-based, suction-dependent dynamic material properties.

This research will advance the fundamental knowledge of unsaturated soil dynamics and seismic performance of geotechnical systems by incorporating the effects of seasonal fluctuation of degree of saturation on site response. The work will assist in better understanding of fundamental mechanism of wave propagation through an unsaturated soil layer. This project will be a substantial step towards more sustainable and safer seismic designs of buildings and infrastructure. The potential findings of the project will help in assessing the performance of current approaches in evaluating the seismic site response and provide practical recommendations to consider the partial saturation in current seismic site response analysis methods. The graduate student development will prepare students to lead the profession through advanced technical training in geotechnical earthquake engineering, water infiltration, and physical modeling, as well as mentoring opportunities. The importance of earthquake engineering and seismic hazards will be introduced to college Civil Engineering and K-12 students through undergraduate research, courses, and outreach programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Seismic waves generated by earthquakes often travel through soils with different mechanical and hydraulic properties. This transition alters the wave characteristics as they ascend from the bedrock to the soil surface. Site response analysis is typically performed in practice to evaluate this process, which is a crucial step toward seismic design of soil-structure systems. Soil’s water content is among the local site conditions that influence the site response, which has received less attention. The seismic response of partially saturated soils differs from that of dry or water saturated soil deposits. Yet, the available site response analysis methods ignore the influence of partial saturation in the soil. Inter-particle suction bonds in partially saturated soils increase the dynamic properties of soils including stiffness, damping, shear wave velocity, and seismic compression. As a result, the distribution of suction with depth is expected to affect the propagation of seismic waves and ground surface accelerations. This, in turn, influences the seismic demand imposed on the soil and surface structures.

This research investigated the effects of partial saturation on the seismic ground response and how different degree of saturation profiles affect the seismic response of a soil layer. The project involved dynamic material characterization, centrifuge physical modeling, and numerical simulation, briefly presented herein;

  • Two very common dynamic geo-material characterization devices, i.e. cyclic triaxial and cyclic direct simple shear, were adapted for testing unsaturated soils. The systems were modified to be able to control the degree of saturation. These two tests impose two completely different loading patterns that soils can experience in the field. However, both can be used to calculate dynamic soil properties including shear modulus measuring soil stiffness and damping showing the dissipated energy in the soil. By desaturating the soil (i.e. increasing the suction) shear modulus increased while damping decreased. The increase in modulus was even noticeable in motions with medium-level induced shear strains. In addition, the seismic compression measured in the direct simple shear test was lower in unsaturated soils highlighting their stiffer response.
  •  Centrifuge testing is a unique scaled physical modeling tool where complex systems can be simulated in higher gravitational field while dimensions are scaled down. However, stresses remain the same, which is important in modeling pressure-dependent geo-materials. A new steady state infiltration system was implemented in the centrifuge facility at the University of New Hampshire. The infiltration process leads to uniform degree of saturation profiles in the soil layers. In this study, a 22.8 cm model sand layer, simulating an 11.4 m deep sand layer in prototype when centrifuge spun at 50 times gravity, was shaken by a scaled Northridge earthquake motion. Different models were prepared and tested where the degree of saturation was altered by changing the discharge velocity during infiltration. The fully instrumented models with several accelerometers in depth and lateral and surficial LVDTs could capture and monitor the site response. The results indicated that the surface-to-base motion amplification level was higher in partially saturated sand layers in comparison with the ones in dry layers, especially in lower degrees of saturation with an average increase of about 16%. This was consistently observed by monitoring different motion intensity measures. On the other hand, lateral deformation and surface seismic settlement that are related to the soil stiffness decreased in partially saturated soils.
  •  A set of numerical models were simulated by incorporating the properties of unsaturated soils in the site response analysis procedures. These analyses were completed for both sandy and silty soils with different uniform degree of saturation profiles in depth. The results confirmed the experimental observations. However, the response contrasted between sand and silt because of the different inter-particle suction level as silts can retain more water in higher suctions.              

The current state of practice for seismic site response analysis relies on procedures that ignore the seasonal variation of degree of saturation in the soil layer. Considering soils in dry or fully saturated conditions are believed to be the worst-case, more conservative scenarios. This study clearly denoted that stiffer response of unsaturated soil layers results in a conservative design should the effect of partial saturation is ignored in deformation analysis. However, the higher motion amplification at the ground surface in partially saturated soils will produce higher seismic demands imposed on the buildings. This can also impact the soil-foundation-structure interaction response of the surface structures. Thus, it is recommended to consider the variability of degree of saturation profile resulted from the seasonal changes of water table in seismic response analysis. Future statistical analysis that incorporates the uncertainty associated with water table level can assist the designers in evaluating the most critical condition for seismic design and to avoid unexpected catastrophic damages to the civil infrastructure.
